did.unittitle: Ordinary People, Extraordinary Lives Oral History Collection

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: New York University. Department of History

physdesc.extent: in 2 manuscript boxes, 2 half manuscript boxes, 1 CD box, and 2 card boxes.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Unless otherwise noted, materials are open for research without restrictions. Any limitations on access, as stipulated in an interviewee's release form, are noted at the interview or series level.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Oral history interviews in this collection were donated by Rachel Bernstein. The date of this donation has not been recorded. There is no accession number associated with these materials. Additional oral histories from Rachel Bernstein's fall 2006 class were donated by Rachel Bernstein, circa 2014. The accession numbers associated with this collection are NPA.2000.268, 2017.039, 2018.069.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this collection organized chronologically.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Ordinary People, Extraordinary Lives Oral History Collection is an ongoing series of life history interviews conducted by graduate students in Professor Rachel Bernstein's oral history classes beginning 1997. Many of the interviews were intended to expand the documentation of the history of work and workers in the NYC area, and to be of use to the Ordinary People, Extraordinary Lives documentation survey, exhibit, book and web exhibit created by Debra Bernhardt and Rachel Bernstein.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Ordinary People, Extraordinary Lives Oral History Collection; OH 073; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection is unprocessed. Materials added to this collection in 2017 were moved into archival housing and described at the collection-level. Field notes were organized by interviewer and placed in box 3: Field Notes. Oral history recordings were added as box 5: Preservation Copies: CDs, 2006.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Other oral history collections documenting working-class New York City life and conducted in connection to Rachel Bernstein's oral history classes include the New York University Department of History Oral History Class Collection (OH 033) and Asian Women United Oral History Collection (OH 074).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Ordinary People, Extraordinary Lives (OPEL) Oral History Collection includes an ongoing series of life history interviews conducted by graduate students in Professor Rachel Bernstein's oral history classes beginning 1997. Interviews in this collection document the history of work and working-class life in New York City. Topics include undocumented aspects of work and family life, political activism, union activism, immigrant experience, domestic life, public health, and religion. Oral histories are accompanied by brief indices prepared by the interviewers for each recording. Oral histories added to the collection in 2017 include 18 interviews recorded in 2006 by students in Bernstein's fall 2006 Oral History course at New York University. Students in the course collected interviews from ordinary New Yorkers about their lives in the city. Interviews from the five students in the course focused on different themes including, life in Stuyvesant Town, gentrification in the Lower East Side, PS. 64 the CHARAS/El Bohio community center, health care on the Lower East Side, and community and class among Chinese immigrants. All interviews were recorded in 2006, and address topics dating from the 1960s to early 2000s.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Access to born-digital material is available via streaming to the NYU network. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by individual narrators and interviewers were transferred to New York University in 2006 by each narrator and interviewer. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library.
